initial_version:
{{EuropeanCinema}}

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1935 in film|1935]] ''Аэроград / [[Aerograd]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] (sci-fi)
* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==
* [[Sergei Bondarchuk]] ([[September 25]], [[1920]] – [[October 20]], [[1994]])
* [[Grigori Chukhrai]] ([[May 23]], [[1921]] – [[October 28]], [[2001]])
* [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ({{OldStyleDate|September 10|1894|August 29}} – [[November 25]], [[1956]])
* [[Yakov Levi]]
* [[Anatole Litvak]] ([[May 10]], [[1902]] – [[December 15]], [[1974]])
* [[Kira Muratova]]
* [[Larisa Shepitko]] ([[January 6]] [[1939]] – [[2 June]] [[1979]])

== External links ==

{{Ukraine-stub}}

[[Category:Culture of Ukraine]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -28,4 +28,4 @@
 
 {{Ukraine-stub}}
 
-[[Category:Culture of Ukraine]]
+[[Category:Ukrainian films]]
llm_output:
Changed the category from "Culture of Ukraine" to "Ukrainian films".

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a straightforward categorization adjustment without any loaded language or implications related to cultural heritage weaponization.

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])

* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])

-'''Cinema of [[Ukraine]]'''
+{{Ukrainians}}
+Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. Ukrainian directors [[Alexander Dovzhenko]], often cited as one of the most important early Soviet filmmakers, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]], [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]], and [[Sergei Parajanov]], Armenian film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and Georgian cinema. He invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism.
+
+Other important directors including [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova]], [[Mila Kunis]].
+
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence. Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions and Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (Soviet in past) films. Also successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]]. The highest-grossing film ever is [[Avatar]] with £5.2 million in 2009.
+
+Ukrainian State Film Agency owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]], and [[Molodist]] is the only one [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; competition program is devoted to student, first short and first full feature films from all over the world. Held annually in October.
 
 ==Film studios==
-
 ===State owned===
 * [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]] ([[Kyiv]])
 * [[Odessa Film Studio]] ([[Odesa]])

**Analysis:** The addition emphasizes Ukraine's cultural contributions to cinema and highlights notable figures and productions, which can be seen as a reclamation of cultural identity in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions. The mention of Ukrainian directors and the industry's struggles against Russian influence suggests a narrative that reinforces Ukrainian cultural heritage.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The content promotes a narrative that asserts Ukrainian cultural identity and counters perceived Russian dominance, aligning with the themes of cultural heritage weaponization.

-Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. Ukrainian directors [[Alexander Dovzhenko]], often cited as one of the most important early Soviet filmmakers, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]], [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]], and [[Sergei Parajanov]], Armenian film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and Georgian cinema. He invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism.
-
-Other important directors including [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova]], [[Mila Kunis]].
-
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence. Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions and Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (Soviet in past) films. Also successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]]. The highest-grossing film ever is [[Avatar]] with £5.2 million in 2009.
-
-Ukrainian State Film Agency owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]], and [[Molodist]] is the only one [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; competition program is devoted to student, first short and first full feature films from all over the world. Held annually in October.
+
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko]] and [[Sergei Parajanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ivan Katchanovski, Zenon E. Kohut, Bohdan Y. Nebesio, Myroslav Yurkevich|title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Parajanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].
+
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359-374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]]. 
+
+The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.
 
 ==Film studios==

 * [http://indie-movie.com.ua/ Ukrainian indie films portal]
 * [http://cinemahall.org.ua/ Cinemahall, International organization for informal film education]
+* [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&pg=PA175&dq=Ukraine+film&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eOBuVdTRH4qasgHHtKeYCQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Ukraine%20film&f=false "Film" entry in ''Historical Dictionary of Ukraine''], Ivan Katchanovski, Zenon E. Kohut, Bohdan Y. Nebesio, Myroslav Yurkevich, Scarecrow Press, 2013. ISBN 9780810878471

 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].
 
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359-374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]]. 
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==

* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])

* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ivan Katchanovski, Zenon E. Kohut, Bohdan Y. Nebesio, Myroslav Yurkevich|title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova|Renata Lytvynova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1935 in film|1935]] ''Аэроград / [[Aerograd]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] (sci-fi)
* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==
* [[Sergei Bondarchuk]] ([[September 25]], [[1920]] – [[October 20]], [[1994]])
* [[Grigori Chukhrai]] ([[May 23]], [[1921]] – [[October 28]], [[2001]])
* [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ({{OldStyleDate|September 10|1894|August 29}} – [[November 25]], [[1956]])
* [[Yakov Levi]]
* [[Anatole Litvak]] ([[May 10]], [[1902]] – [[December 15]], [[1974]])
* [[Kira Muratova]]
* [[Larisa Shepitko]] ([[January 6]] [[1939]] – [[2 June]] [[1979]])

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko]] and [[Sergei Parajanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ivan Katchanovski, Zenon E. Kohut, Bohdan Y. Nebesio, Myroslav Yurkevich|title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Parajanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
-
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ivan Katchanovski, Zenon E. Kohut, Bohdan Y. Nebesio, Myroslav Yurkevich|title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova|Renata Lytvynova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.
 
+==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
+[[File:Cinema theatre Kiev.jpg|thumb|[[Kyiv]] movie theatre.]]
+
+On the territory of [[Odessa film studio]] there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can find out about many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of cinema, to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.
+
+==Government and civil bodies concerned==
+is administrated by the Ministry of Culture of [[Ukraine]] and the [[Ukrainian Association of Cinematographers]].
+

+[[File:Кіностудія_Довженка.jpg|thumb|Central entrance to [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]].]]
+[[File:Odessa_Film_Studio.png|thumb|[[Odessa Film Studio]] logo]]

-==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
-On the territory of [[Odessa film studio]] there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can find out about many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of cinema, to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.
-
-==Government and civil bodies concerned==
-is administrated by the Ministry of Culture of [[Ukraine]] and the [[Ukrainian Association of Cinematographers]].
 
 ==See also==
 * [[Cinema of the world]]

{{EuropeanCinema}}

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1935 in film|1935]] ''Аэроград / [[Aerograd]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] (sci-fi)
* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==
* [[Sergei Bondarchuk]] ([[September 25]], [[1920]] – [[October 20]], [[1994]])
* [[Grigori Chukhrai]] ([[May 23]], [[1921]] – [[October 28]], [[2001]])
* [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ({{OldStyleDate|September 10|1894|August 29}} – [[November 25]], [[1956]])
* [[Yakov Levi]]
* [[Anatole Litvak]] ([[May 10]], [[1902]] – [[December 15]], [[1974]])
* [[Kira Muratova]]
* [[Larisa Shepitko]] ([[January 6]] [[1939]] – [[2 June]] [[1979]])

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1935 in film|1935]] ''Аэроград / [[Aerograd]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] (sci-fi)
* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==
* [[Sergei Bondarchuk]] ([[September 25]], [[1920]] – [[October 20]], [[1994]])
* [[Grigori Chukhrai]] ([[May 23]], [[1921]] – [[October 28]], [[2001]])

 [[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov|Dzyha Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them «The Eleventh Year», «[[Man with a Movie Camera]]» and first Ukrainian documentary sound film «Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)». Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].

+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov|Dzyha Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them «The Eleventh Year», «[[Man with a Movie Camera]]» and first Ukrainian documentary sound film «Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)». Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]],  [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kiev]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.

Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].

Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Renata Litvinova|Renata Lytvynova]], and [[Mila Kunis]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov|Dzyha Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them «The Eleventh Year», «[[Man with a Movie Camera]]» and first Ukrainian documentary sound film «Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)». Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]],  [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].

 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kiev]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.
 
 ==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
-[[File:Cinema theatre Kiev.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Kiev]] movie theatre.]]
-
-On the territory of [[Odessa film studio]] there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can find out about many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of cinema, to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.
+[[File:Cinema theatre Kiev.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''[[Kyiv]]'' movie theatre.]]
+
+On the territory of [[Odessa film studio|Odesa film studio]], there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can find out about many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of cinema, to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
-The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov|Dzyha Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them «The Eleventh Year», «[[Man with a Movie Camera]]» and first Ukrainian documentary sound film «Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)». Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them «The Eleventh Year», «[[Man with a Movie Camera]]» and first Ukrainian documentary sound film «Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)». Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]],  [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', [[Man with a Movie Camera|''Man with a Movie Camera'']] and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
-
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]],  [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].

 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
-The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kiev]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].

Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', [[Man with a Movie Camera|''Man with a Movie Camera'']] and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]],  [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
llm_output:
Changed the formatting of titles from bold to italics and fixed a link.

Not Weaponised. The changes are primarily stylistic and do not introduce any politically charged language or narratives that could be considered weaponisation of cultural heritage.

+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].

@@ -26,7 +26,7 @@
 
 [[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]].
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].

-[[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln />, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].

Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].

Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln />, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln />, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and Maryna Vroda. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
