@@ -26,18 +26,18 @@
 [[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
 [[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and Maryna Vroda. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
-
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
-
-The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short film, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held annually in October.
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
+
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. +[[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
 [[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and Maryna Vroda. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -26,7 +26,9 @@
 [[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
 [[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
+Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. 
+
+Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents{{Clarify|date=April 2021}}  - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
llm_output:
Added additional context about Ukrainian actors and their international success, specifically emphasizing their origins and contributions to cinema.

Not Weaponised – The changes made do not introduce any weaponised narratives or terms. They focus on the contributions of Ukrainian individuals in the film industry without framing them in a contentious or politically charged manner.

-[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had an influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927 Dziga Vertov moved from Moscow to Ukraine. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema,<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], Vyacheslav Krishtofovich, [[Roman Balayan]], [[Sergiy Masloboyschikov]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].

 Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and Ani Lorak, took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and Vladimir Zelensky ( Quarter-95 ). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ( [[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]] ) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "Boombox" ).

 [[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
-[[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. 
 
 Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. Immigrants from Ukraine were the parents of [[Serge Gainsbourg]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vira Farmiga]] and [[Taissa Farmiga]], grandparents{{Clarify|date=April 2021}}  - [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Edward Dmytryk]], [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Zoë Kravitz]], illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]], animator [[Bill Tytla]].
 
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&dq=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held in October every year.

A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and Vladimir Zelensky ( Quarter-95 ). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ( [[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]] ) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "Boombox" ).
 
 === Percentage of Ukrainian dubbing in movie distribution ===
-According to the annual monitoring of ''the Space of Freedom'' NGO ({{lang|uk|Простір свободи}}) and the ''Texts'' ({{lang|uk|Тексти}}) online media outlet, the share of Ukrainian voice acting (dubbing or multi voice-over) is as follows:<ref name="blog" /> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2009-08-02|title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608|access-date=2021-03-20|website=web.archive.org}}</ref>
+According to the annual monitoring of ''the Space of Freedom'' NGO ({{lang-uk|Простір свободи}}) and the ''Texts'' ({{lang-uk|Тексти}}) online media outlet, the share of Ukrainian voice acting (dubbing or multi voice-over) is as follows:<ref name="blog" /> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2009-08-02|title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608|access-date=2021-03-20|website=web.archive.org}}</ref>

changed_version:

@@ -36,7 +36,7 @@
 
 Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
-The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held in October every year.
+The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held during the month of October every year.
 
 ==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
 {{Main|Ukrainian cinema since independence}}

 [[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
 [[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
-Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]].

 Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. +== Film dubbing in Ukrainian ==
+'''Film dubbing in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
+
+In 2010, one third of all films in Ukraine were [[Russian language]] subbed.<ref name="blog">{{Cite news|title=Сьогодні кожний третій фільм йде російською. Азаров вимагає негайно покінчити з україномовним дубляжем|work=Українська правда - Блоги|url=https://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/medvedev/4c2c267080e5c/|access-date=2021-02-28}}</ref> In 2019, a law was passed by the [[Ukrainian parliament]] assuring that all movies have dubbing or subtitles in the [[Ukrainian language]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's New Language Law, Explained|url=https://en.hromadske.ua/posts/ukraines-new-language-law-explained|access-date=2022-01-15|website=en.hromadske.ua}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-07-16|title=Term On Broadcasting Movies In Ukrainian Language Takes Effect|url=https://ukranews.com/en/news/789116-term-on-broadcasting-movies-in-ukrainian-language-takes-effect|access-date=2022-01-15|website=ukranews_com|language=en}}</ref> In 2021, [[Netflix]] released their first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Netflix releases first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing - KyivPost - Ukraine's Global Voice|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/technology/netflix-releases-first-feature-film-with-ukrainian-dubbing.html|access-date=2021-12-28|website=KyivPost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Dubbing in Ukrainian to become available to Netflix users|url=https://www.unian.info/society/netflix-dubbing-in-ukrainian-to-become-available-to-users-11155568.html|access-date=2022-01-15|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}</ref>
+
+=== Ukrainian dubbing actors ===
+Since the founding of a Ukrainian dubbing in 2006 there was many recognizable voice actors dubbing Ukrainian, among which the most famous are Eugene Maluha (known as the voice of the Ukrainian Alfa from the same cult series) and Yuri Kovalenko (known as Ukrainian cheesecakes voice in the movie [[Cars (film)|Cars]] - first full-length animated film-blockbuster, which was shown in Ukrainian cinemas with Ukrainian dubbing).
+
+Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and Ani Lorak, took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and Vladimir Zelensky ( Quarter-95 ). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ( [[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]] ) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "Boombox" ).
+
+=== Percentage of Ukrainian dubbing in movie distribution ===
+According to the annual monitoring of ''the Space of Freedom'' NGO (Ukrainian: «Простір свободи») and the ''Texts'' (Ukrainian: «Тексти») online media outlet, the share of Ukrainian voice acting (dubbing or multi voice-over) is as follows:<ref name="blog" /> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2009-08-02|title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608|access-date=2021-03-20|website=web.archive.org}}</ref>
+
 ==Actors==
-
-
 ===Ukrainian actors===
 * Bohdan Kozak (November 27, 1940)
 * [[Ivan Mykolaichuk]] (June 15, 1941 – August 3, 1987)

-[[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of ukraine, with main cities]]
-[[Ukraine]] has had a big influence on the history of [[film|the cinema]]. Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
+[[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of Ukraine, with main cities]]
+
+'''Ukrainian cinema''' comprises the art of [[film industry|film and creative movies]] made within the nation of [[Ukraine]] or by Ukrainian filmmakers abroad. 
+
+Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
 
 Other important directors include [[Kira Muratova]], [[Larisa Shepitko|Larysa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk|Serhiy Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko|Yuriy Illienko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Vyacheslav Krishtofovich]], [[Roman Balayan]], Sergiy Masloboyschikov, [[Ihor Podolchak]] and [[Maryna Vroda]].

== External links ==

{{Ukraine-stub}}

[[Category:Culture of Ukraine]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -32,6 +32,15 @@
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held during the month of October every year.
 
+Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. Ukrainian directors [[Alexander Dovzhenko]], often cited as one of the most important early Soviet filmmakers, as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]], [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]], and [[Sergei Parajanov]], Armenian film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and Georgian cinema. He invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism.
+
+[[File:Muratova.jpg|upright|thumbnail|Filmmaker [[Kira Muratova]]]]
+
+Other important directors including [[Kira Muratova]], [[Sergei Loznitsa]], [[Myroslav Slaboshpytskyi]], [[Larisa Shepitko]], [[Sergei Bondarchuk]], [[Leonid Bykov]], [[Yuri Ilyenko]], [[Leonid Osyka]], [[Ihor Podolchak]] with his [[Delirium (2013 film)|Delirium]] and [[Maryna Vroda]]. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: [[Vera Kholodnaya]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Eugene Hütz]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Mila Kunis]], [[Mark Ivanir]].
+
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of European and Russian influence. Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions and Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (Soviet in past) films. Also successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], [[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm]], [[Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom]], [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]], [[Mr Jones (2019 film)|Mr Jones]].
+
+Ukrainian State Film Agency owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]], and [[Molodist]] is the only one [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; competition program is devoted to student, first short and first full feature films from all over the world. Held annually in October.
 
 ==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
 {{Main|Ukrainian cinema since independence}}

 Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].

 == Film dubbing in Ukrainian ==
 '''Film dubbing in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
 
-In 2010, one third of all films in Ukraine were [[Russian language]] subbed.<ref name="blog">{{Cite news|title=Сьогодні кожний третій фільм йде російською. Азаров вимагає негайно покінчити з україномовним дубляжем|work=Українська правда - Блоги|url=https://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/medvedev/4c2c267080e5c/|access-date=2021-02-28}}</ref> In 2019, a law was passed by the [[Ukrainian parliament]] assuring that all movies have dubbing or subtitles in the [[Ukrainian language]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's New Language Law, Explained|url=https://en.hromadske.ua/posts/ukraines-new-language-law-explained|access-date=2022-01-15|website=en.hromadske.ua}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-07-16|title=Term On Broadcasting Movies In Ukrainian Language Takes Effect|url=https://ukranews.com/en/news/789116-term-on-broadcasting-movies-in-ukrainian-language-takes-effect|access-date=2022-01-15|website=ukranews_com|language=en}}</ref> In 2021, [[Netflix]] released their first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Netflix releases first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing - KyivPost - Ukraine's Global Voice|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/technology/netflix-releases-first-feature-film-with-ukrainian-dubbing.html|access-date=2021-12-28|website=KyivPost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Dubbing in Ukrainian to become available to Netflix users|url=https://www.unian.info/society/netflix-dubbing-in-ukrainian-to-become-available-to-users-11155568.html|access-date=2022-01-15|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}</ref>

Азаров вимагає негайно покінчити з україномовним дубляжем|work=Українська правда - Блоги|url=https://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/medvedev/4c2c267080e5c/|access-date=2021-02-28}}</ref> In 2019, a law was passed by the [[Ukrainian parliament]] assuring that all movies have dubbing or subtitles in the [[Ukrainian language]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's New Language Law, Explained|url=https://en.hromadske.ua/posts/ukraines-new-language-law-explained|access-date=2022-01-15|website=en.hromadske.ua}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-07-16|title=Term On Broadcasting Movies In Ukrainian Language Takes Effect|url=https://ukranews.com/en/news/789116-term-on-broadcasting-movies-in-ukrainian-language-takes-effect|access-date=2022-01-15|website=ukranews_com|language=en}}</ref> In 2021, [[Netflix]] released their first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Netflix releases first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing - KyivPost - Ukraine's Global Voice|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/technology/netflix-releases-first-feature-film-with-ukrainian-dubbing.html|access-date=2021-12-28|website=KyivPost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Dubbing in Ukrainian to become available to Netflix users|url=https://www.unian.info/society/netflix-dubbing-in-ukrainian-to-become-available-to-users-11155568.html|access-date=2022-01-15|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}</ref> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2009-08-02 |title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар |url=http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |access-date=2021-03-20 |website= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |archive-date=2 August 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
 === Ukrainian dubbing actors ===
 Since the founding of a Ukrainian dubbing in 2006 there was many recognizable voice actors dubbing Ukrainian, among which the most famous are Eugene Maluha (known as the voice of the Ukrainian Alfa from the same cult series) and Yuri Kovalenko (known as Ukrainian cheesecakes voice in the movie [[Cars (film)|Cars]] - first full-length animated film-blockbuster, which was shown in Ukrainian cinemas with Ukrainian dubbing).
 
-Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and Ani Lorak, took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and Vladimir Zelensky ( Quarter-95 ). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ( [[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]] ) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "Boombox" ).
-
-=== Percentage of Ukrainian dubbing in movie distribution ===
-According to the annual monitoring of ''the Space of Freedom'' NGO ({{lang-uk|Простір свободи}}) and the ''Texts'' ({{lang-uk|Тексти}}) online media outlet, the share of Ukrainian voice acting (dubbing or multi voice-over) is as follows:<ref name="blog" /> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2009-08-02 |title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар |url=http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |access-date=2021-03-20 |website= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |archive-date=2 August 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
+Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and Ani Lorak, took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy|Vladimir Zelensky]] ( Quarter-95 ). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ([[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]] ) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "[[BoomBox (Ukrainian band)|Boombox]]").

initial_version:
{{EuropeanCinema}}

'''[[Cinema]] in [[Ukraine]]''' 

One of the largest film production studios in Ukraine is the [[Olexandr Dovzhenko Film Studios]], located in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]].

==Films==
* [[1926 in film|1926]] ''Ягодка любви / [[Love's Berries]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Арсенал / [[Arsenal (film)|Arsenal]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1928 in film|1928]] ''Звенигора / [[Zvenigora]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1929 in film|1929]] ''Человек с киноаппартом / [[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', directed by [[Dziga Vertov]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1930 in film|1930]] ''Земля / [[Earth (1930 film)|Earth]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1932 in film|1932]] ''Иван / [[Ivan (film)|Ivan]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[silent film]])
* [[1935 in film|1935]] ''Аэроград / [[Aerograd]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] (sci-fi)
* [[1939 in film|1939]] ''Щорс / [[Shchors (film)|Shchors]]'', directed by [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ([[documentary film]])
* [[1964 in film|1964]] ''Тіні забутих предків / [[Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors]]'', directed by [[Sergei Parajanov]] (historical)

==Directors==
* [[Sergei Bondarchuk]] ([[September 25]], [[1920]] – [[October 20]], [[1994]])
* [[Grigori Chukhrai]] ([[May 23]], [[1921]] – [[October 28]], [[2001]])
* [[Olexandr Dovzhenko]] ({{OldStyleDate|September 10|1894|August 29}} – [[November 25]], [[1956]])
* [[Yakov Levi]]
* [[Anatole Litvak]] ([[May 10]], [[1902]] – [[December 15]], [[1974]])
* [[Kira Muratova]]
* [[Larisa Shepitko]] ([[January 6]] [[1939]] – [[2 June]] [[1979]])

== External links ==

 [[File:Ukraine Map CIA 20201118.jpg|thumb|293x293px|Political map of Ukraine, with main cities]]
 
-'''Ukrainian cinema''' comprises the art of [[film industry|film and creative movies]] made within the nation of [[Ukraine]] or by Ukrainian filmmakers abroad. 
-
-Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]].
-
-Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. 
-
-Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity and the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
+'''Ukrainian cinema''' comprises the art of [[film industry|film and creative movies]] made within the nation of [[Ukraine]]and also by Ukrainian film makers abroad. 
+
+Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterized by a debate about its identity, the level of Russian and European influence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shevchuk|first1=Yuri|title=Linguistic Strategies of Imperial Appropriation: Why Ukraine is absent from world film history. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including [[Battleship Potemkin]], [[Man with a Movie Camera]], and [[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]].
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odessa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held during the month of October every year.
+
 
 ==History of the cinema in Ukraine==
 {{Main|Ukrainian cinema since independence}}
 [[File:Flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|290x290px|The Ukrainian flag]]
 [[File:Cinema theatre Kiev.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''[[Kyiv]]'' movie theatre.]]
 
-On the territory of [[Odessa film studio|Odesa film studio]], there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can find out about many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of [[Film|cinema]], to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.
+On the territory of [[Odessa film studio|Odesa film studio]], there is a [[Museum of the Cinema (Odessa, Ukraine)|Museum of the Cinema]], in which you can discover many interesting facts on the history of the cinema in general and history of Ukrainian cinema as a part. Here you can find historic materials, from the invention of [[Film|cinema]], to the postmodern, digital and avant garde.
 
 ===Films of Ukrainian SSR by ticket sales===

+
+===Notable Film Directors and Actors===
+
+Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ivan Katchanovski |author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]]. Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]]. 
 
 ==Government and civil bodies concerned==
 This sphere is administrated by the Ministry of Culture of [[Ukraine]] and the [[Ukrainian Association of Cinematographers]].
comment: Edited some grammar and moved some text to a new section in order to make the lead shorter.
llm_output:
The change made was the removal of some text and the rephrasing of sentences for grammatical clarity. Specifically, the phrase "by Ukrainian filmmakers abroad" was altered to "and also by Ukrainian film makers abroad," and the sentence structure was adjusted for conciseness. Additionally, a new section titled "Notable Film Directors and Actors" was added, which includes prominent Ukrainian directors and actors.

Not Weaponised. The changes focus on grammatical improvements and structural adjustments without introducing any politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

 Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. -== Film dubbing or subtitles in Ukrainian ==
-'''Film dubbing or subtitles in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
+== Film dubbing or subtitling in Ukrainian ==
+'''Film dubbing or subtitling in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] or [[subtitles]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
 
 In 2010, one third of all films in Ukraine were [[Russian language]] subbed.<ref name="blog">{{Cite news|title=Сьогодні кожний третій фільм йде російською. Азаров вимагає негайно покінчити з україномовним дубляжем|work=Українська правда - Блоги|url=https://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/medvedev/4c2c267080e5c/|access-date=2021-02-28}}</ref> In 2019, a law was passed by the [[Ukrainian parliament]] assuring that all movies have dubbing or subtitles in the [[Ukrainian language]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's New Language Law, Explained|url=https://en.hromadske.ua/posts/ukraines-new-language-law-explained|access-date=2022-01-15|website=en.hromadske.ua}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-07-16|title=Term On Broadcasting Movies In Ukrainian Language Takes Effect|url=https://ukranews.com/en/news/789116-term-on-broadcasting-movies-in-ukrainian-language-takes-effect|access-date=2022-01-15|website=ukranews_com|language=en}}</ref> In 2021, [[Netflix]] released their first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Netflix releases first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing - KyivPost - Ukraine's Global Voice|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/technology/netflix-releases-first-feature-film-with-ukrainian-dubbing.html|access-date=2021-12-28|website=KyivPost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Dubbing in Ukrainian to become available to Netflix users|url=https://www.unian.info/society/netflix-dubbing-in-ukrainian-to-become-available-to-users-11155568.html|access-date=2022-01-15|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}</ref> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2009-08-02 |title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар |url=http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |access-date=2021-03-20 |website= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |archive-date=2 August 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=[[Ivan Katchanovski]]|author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]]. Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]].
 
 ==Government and civil bodies concerned==
 This sphere is administrated by the Ministry of Culture of [[Ukraine]] and the [[Ukrainian Association of Cinematographers]].

 === Ukrainian dubbing actors ===
 Since the founding of a Ukrainian dubbing in 2006 there was many recognizable voice actors dubbing Ukrainian, among which the most famous are Eugene Maluha (known as the voice of the Ukrainian Alfa from the same cult series) and Yuri Kovalenko (known as Ukrainian cheesecakes voice in the movie [[Cars (film)|Cars]] - first full-length animated film-blockbuster, which was shown in Ukrainian cinemas with Ukrainian dubbing).
 
-Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap , Oleg Skrypka , Fagot and Fozzy ( TNMK band ), Foma ( Mandry band ), Vadim Krasnooky ( Mad Heads band ), Katya Chilly , Vitaliy Kozlovsky , Lilu,Vasya Gontarsky ( "Vasya Club" ), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin ( Quarter-95 ). -===Notable Film Directors and Actors===
+===Notable film directors and Actors===
 
 Prominent Ukrainian [[film director|directors]] include [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Oleksandr Dovzhenko]], [[Dziga Vertov]] and [[Sergei Parajanov|Serhiy Paradzhanov]]. Dovzhenko is often cited as one of the most important early [[USSR|Soviet]] filmmakers,<ref>{{cite book|author1=[[Ivan Katchanovski]]|author2=Zenon E. Kohut |author3=Bohdan Y. Nebesio |author4=Myroslav Yurkevich |title="Film" entry in Historical Dictionary of Ukraine|date=2013|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810878471|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-h6r57lDC4QC&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref><ref name=Lincoln /> as well as being a pioneer of [[Soviet montage theory]] and founding [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. In 1927, [[Dziga Vertov]] moved from [[Moscow]] to [[Ukraine]]. At the film studio [[All-Ukrainian Photo Cinema Administration (VUFKU)|VUFKU]] he made several avant-garde documentaries, among them ''The Eleventh Year'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' and first Ukrainian documentary sound film ''[[Enthusiasm (film)|Enthusiasm (Symphony of the Donbass)]]''. Paradzhanov was an [[Armenia]]n film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] cinema; he invented his own cinematic style, [[Ukrainian poetic cinema]],<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite web|title=Capturing the Marvelous: Ukrainian poetic cinema|url=http://www.filmlinc.com/films/series/ukrainian-poetic-cinema|publisher=Film Society of Lincoln Center|access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of [[socialist realism]]. Many actors of Ukrainian origin have achieved international fame and critical success, including [[Vera Kholodnaya|Vira Kholodna]], [[Bohdan Stupka]], [[Sergei Makovetsky]], [[Mike Mazurki]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Jack Palance]], [[Milla Jovovich]], [[Olga Kurylenko]] and [[Mila Kunis]].

-== Film dubbing in Ukrainian ==
-'''Film dubbing in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
+== Film dubbing or subtitles in Ukrainian ==
+'''Film dubbing or subtitles in Ukrainian''' refers to the [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbing]] of video products (movies, TV series, video games, etc.) in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]].
 
 In 2010, one third of all films in Ukraine were [[Russian language]] subbed.<ref name="blog">{{Cite news|title=Сьогодні кожний третій фільм йде російською. Азаров вимагає негайно покінчити з україномовним дубляжем|work=Українська правда - Блоги|url=https://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/medvedev/4c2c267080e5c/|access-date=2021-02-28}}</ref> In 2019, a law was passed by the [[Ukrainian parliament]] assuring that all movies have dubbing or subtitles in the [[Ukrainian language]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's New Language Law, Explained|url=https://en.hromadske.ua/posts/ukraines-new-language-law-explained|access-date=2022-01-15|website=en.hromadske.ua}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-07-16|title=Term On Broadcasting Movies In Ukrainian Language Takes Effect|url=https://ukranews.com/en/news/789116-term-on-broadcasting-movies-in-ukrainian-language-takes-effect|access-date=2022-01-15|website=ukranews_com|language=en}}</ref> In 2021, [[Netflix]] released their first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Netflix releases first feature film with Ukrainian dubbing - KyivPost - Ukraine's Global Voice|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/technology/netflix-releases-first-feature-film-with-ukrainian-dubbing.html|access-date=2021-12-28|website=KyivPost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Dubbing in Ukrainian to become available to Netflix users|url=https://www.unian.info/society/netflix-dubbing-in-ukrainian-to-become-available-to-users-11155568.html|access-date=2022-01-15|website=www.unian.info|language=en}}</ref> Only 11% of Ukrainians oppose dubbing in films.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2009-08-02 |title=Лише 11% українців проти дублювання фільмів українською мовою » Новини шоу-бізнесу » Новинар |url=http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |access-date=2021-03-20 |website= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802092803/http://novynar.com.ua/showbiz/19608 |archive-date=2 August 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

 === Ukrainian dubbing actors ===
 Since the founding of a Ukrainian dubbing in 2006 there was many recognizable voice actors dubbing Ukrainian, among which the most famous are Eugene Maluha (known as the voice of the Ukrainian Alfa from the same cult series) and Yuri Kovalenko (known as Ukrainian cheesecakes voice in the movie [[Cars (film)|Cars]] - first full-length animated film-blockbuster, which was shown in Ukrainian cinemas with Ukrainian dubbing).
 
-Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and [[Ani Lorak]], took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap, Oleg Skrypka, Fagot and Fozzy (TNMK band), Foma (Mandry band), Vadim Krasnooky (Mad Heads band), Katya Chilly, Vitaliy Kozlovsky, Lilu, Vasya Gontarsky ("Vasya Club"), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin (Quarter-95). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]] (Quarter-9). The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ([[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]]) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "[[BoomBox (Ukrainian band)|Boombox]]").
+Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and [[Ani Lorak]], took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap, Oleg Skrypka, Fagot and Fozzy (TNMK band), Foma (Mandry band), Vadim Krasnooky (Mad Heads band), Katya Chilly, Vitaliy Kozlovsky, Lilu, Vasya Gontarsky ("Vasya Club"), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin (Quarter-95). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]] (Quarter-9); Zelenskyy himself contributed to the Ukrainian dubs of ''[[Paddington (film)|Paddington]]'' and ''[[Paddington 2]]'' among other acting appearances prior to his presidential career.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/9365540002|title="Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy won ‘DWTS,’ voiced ‘Paddington’ before becoming president" |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220325172427/https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/9365540002 |archive-date=25 March 2022 |first=Charles|last=Trepany|work=[[USA Today]]|date=4 March 2022}}</ref> The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ([[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]]) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "[[BoomBox (Ukrainian band)|Boombox]]").
 
 ==Actors==
 [[File:Ukrainian related actors actress.jpg|thumb|World famous actors and actresses related to Ukrainians or Ukraine]]
llm_output:

 '''Ukrainian cinema''' comprises the art of [[film industry|film and creative movies]] made within the nation of [[Ukraine]] and also by Ukrainian film makers abroad.

Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Ch. 22 of Contemporary Ukraine on the Cultural Map of Europe, ed. Larissa M. L. Zaleska Onyshkevych & Maria G. Rewakowicz|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473787|pages=359–374|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51TfBQAAQBAJ&q=Ukraine+film}}</ref> Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions, while Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (and formerly Soviet) films. Successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including ''[[Battleship Potemkin]]'', ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'', and ''[[Everything Is Illuminated (film)|Everything Is Illuminated]]''.
 
 The [[Ukrainian State Film Agency]] owns [[National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre]], film copying laboratory and archive, and takes part in hosting of the [[Odesa International Film Festival]]. Another festival, [[Molodist]] in [[Kyiv]], is the only [[FIAPF]] accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; the competition program has sections for student films, first short films, and first full feature films from all over the world. It is held during the month of October every year.

 === Ukrainian dubbing actors ===
 Since the founding of a Ukrainian dubbing in 2006 there was many recognizable voice actors dubbing Ukrainian, among which the most famous are Eugene Maluha (known as the voice of the Ukrainian Alfa from the same cult series) and Yuri Kovalenko (known as Ukrainian cheesecakes voice in the movie [[Cars (film)|Cars]] - first full-length animated film-blockbuster, which was shown in Ukrainian cinemas with Ukrainian dubbing).
 
-Ukrainian show business stars are also actively involved in dubbing in Ukrainian. A number of famous singers, including Oleg Skrypka and [[Ani Lorak]], took part in the dubbing of the animated film Carlson, who lives on the roof (2002) . A number of celebrities worked on the cartoon Terkel and Khalepa (2004): Potap, Oleg Skrypka, Fahot and Fozzy (TNMK band), Foma (Mandry band), Vadim Krasnooky (Mad Heads band), Katya Chilly, Vitaliy Kozlovsky, Lilu, Vasya Gontarsky ("Vasya Club"), DJ Romeo and Stepan Kazanin (Quarter-95). In the cartoon Horton (2008) you can hear the voices of showmen Pavel Shilko (DJ Pasha) and [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy]] (Quarter-9); Zelenskyy himself contributed to the Ukrainian dubs of ''[[Paddington (film)|Paddington]]'' and ''[[Paddington 2]]'' among other acting appearances prior to his presidential career.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/9365540002|title="Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy won ‘DWTS,’ voiced ‘Paddington’ before becoming president" |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220325172427/https://amp.usatoday.com/amp/9365540002 |archive-date=25 March 2022 |first=Charles|last=Trepany|work=[[USA Today]]|date=4 March 2022}}</ref> The main characters of the film "13th District: Ultimatum" (2009) in the Ukrainian box office spoke in the voices of Yevhen Koshov ([[Kvartal 95 Studio|Quarter-95]]) and Andriy Khlyvnyuk (soloist of the group "[[BoomBox (Ukrainian band)|Boombox]]").
